descriptions:
Here is a 296-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Revealing Earliest Animal Domestication in the Fertile Crescent

This project aims to unravel the enigmatic origins of animal domestication in the Fertile Crescent, a crucial region for understanding the Neolithic transition. Focusing on early evidences of sheep and goat management, we will employ biogeochemical analyses on fossil teeth to investigate the mechanisms underlying animal domestication. Specifically, we will examine how humans controlled animals' reproductive cycles, altered their feeding habits, and interrupted their migratory-seasonal movements.

Our research will target faunal assemblages, wild relatives in museum collections, and current living populations in breeding centers across three key regions: the Southern Levant, Northern Levant, and Eastern Fertile Crescent. By integrating these approaches, we seek to challenge existing paradigms on the origin of animal domesticates and identify how human societies transformed animals through domestication.

Our project goals are threefold: (1) to discover early caprine management practices, (2) to establish when and where animal domestication processes began, and (3) to understand how human societies changed animals through domestication. By achieving these goals, our project will provide a groundbreaking understanding of the earliest animal domestication in the Fertile Crescent, shedding light on the complex relationships between humans and animals that have shaped our world. This knowledge will have significant implications for our understanding of the Neolithic transition, the development of complex societies, and the conservation of biodiversity.
